args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a concrete example or illustrative instance of the more general type or category represented by the object.
args.justification: The pyramids at Giza are described as an example of elaborate ancient Egyptian tombs, expressing an instance–category example relation rather than strict class membership.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an action, service, or ritual is performed for the benefit of a particular person or group.
args.justification: Ancient Egyptian burial practices are explicitly said to be performed for the deceased, which is a beneficiary/for-whom relation for an action.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a material or treatment is applied to the body of a person or entity.
args.justification: Linen bandages are used to wrap the deceased's body, which is a specific application of a material to a body, not a general usage or composition relation.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is conceptually or ritually intended to reunite with the object.
args.justification: The soul is said to be associated with and meant to reunite with the deceased's body, emphasizing a future-intended reunion rather than a generic association.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a text or inscription is written or recorded on a particular physical medium.
args.justification: The Book of the Dead is written on papyrus scrolls, capturing a text-to-physical-medium relationship.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a ritual or action is performed with the purpose of honoring or paying respect to the object.
args.justification: Funerary rituals are described as being performed to honor the deceased, so the key predicate is the honoring purpose of the ritual.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an object or structure is intended or used to serve a particular purpose, goal, or desired state.
args.justification: Both ancient Egyptian tombs and amulets are described as being meant to ensure safe passage or eternal existence in the afterlife; they share the same object-purpose semantics and can be normalized to a single purpose predicate.
The relation links a specific instance (pyramids at Giza) to a general category (ancient Egyptian tombs) as an illustrative example, fitting an example/instance class.
The burial practices (rituals) are performed for the deceased as the beneficiary, placing this in a family of relations where rituals or actions have explicit beneficiaries.
Linen bandages are applied to the deceased's body, aligning with relations where a treatment or material is applied to a body or object.
The relation expresses the intended reunion between the soul and the deceased's body in the afterlife, a specific type of conceptual/ritual reunion relation.
The papyrus scroll serves as the physical carrier of the Book of the Dead text, which fits an information-to-medium/carrier relation class.
Funerary rituals are linked to their purpose of honoring the deceased, representing a family of relations connecting rituals to their intended purposes.

Both relations describe funerary objects or structures (tombs, amulets) in terms of the afterlife purposes they serve, so they belong in a common object-purpose relation class within funerary context.
An example-instance link is a type of classificatory/identity relation between a specific entity and a broader category.
The relation concerns an action (ritual practice) and its beneficiary, which falls under agentive/action-target semantics.
Applying bandages to a body alters its state and appearance, fitting a broad modification/treatment category.
The intended reunion of the soul with the deceased's body is a conceptual and ritual association between two entities, not a physical composition or location.
Papyrus scrolls are used as a medium to carry the Book of the Dead text, a typical usage/function-of-material relation.
The funerary rituals are performed with the explicit purpose of honoring the deceased, expressing a purpose/causal-intent relation.
Tombs and amulets are described in terms of the purposes they serve (ensuring safe passage or eternal existence), aligning with usage/function-of-object semantics.

cluster_classes.class_description: Social groups within ancient Egyptian society distinguished by status and burial practices, including both elite and non-elite non-royal populations.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: High-status non-royal individuals... and common people in ancient Egypt, both described as social groups differentiated by status.

members.entity_description: High-status non-royal individuals in ancient Egyptian society who were granted elaborate tombs and burials.
Typical, non-elite members of ancient Egyptian society who, despite lacking the resources of the elite, were buried with care, respect, and items for use in the afterlife.

cluster_classes.class_description: Monumental tomb constructions in ancient Egypt, including pyramids and related burial complexes built to house the dead and support their afterlife.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: complex burial structures in ancient Egypt, including pyramids and monumental tombs such as the pyramids at Giza

members.entity_description: Complex, carefully constructed burial structures and chambers in ancient Egypt, including pyramids and other monumental tombs, built to house the deceased and their funerary goods and to ensure their passage into the afterlife.
Large monumental pyramid structures in ancient Egypt built as tombs to house and protect the deceased.
Famous pyramid complexes on the Giza Plateau built as monumental tombs for Egyptian rulers.

cluster_classes.class_description: Collective representations of ancient Egypt as a historical civilization, including its people, culture, and social structures.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: ancient Egyptian burial practices were a vital part of Egyptian culture and society... people of ancient Egypt... overall cultural system of ancient Egypt

members.entity_description: The people of ancient Egypt, responsible for developing and practicing the civilization's religious, social, and funerary customs, including mummification and tomb burials.
Historical civilization along the Nile River in northeastern Africa, known for its complex culture, elaborate burial practices, and monumental architecture.
The social, religious, artistic, and broader cultural traditions and practices that characterized the civilization of ancient Egypt.
The social structure, institutions, and communal life of ancient Egypt, including relationships between different social groups and classes.

cluster_classes.class_description: Supreme monarchs who governed ancient Egypt and for whom monumental tombs, such as pyramids, were constructed as burial places.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: monumental structures were built to house the pharaohs and other important individuals in the afterlife

members.entity_description: Rulers of ancient Egypt for whom monumental tombs like pyramids were constructed.

args.new_class_group: Ancient Egypt: Society, Rulers, and Funerary Culture

args.new_class_group: Ancient Egypt: Society, Rulers, and Funerary Culture

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject functions in the role or capacity expressed by the object.
args.justification: This relation connects the Egyptian pyramids to their conceptual role as a gateway to the afterlife; a generic functional predicate 'serves_as' accurately captures that the subject fulfills the role denoted by the object.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject provides, supplies, or contributes a beneficial outcome or resource expressed by the object.
args.justification: In all three instances, funerary offerings (food, clothing, jewelry) are said to provide or contribute to specific benefits (sustenance or comfort) in the afterlife; a single predicate 'provides_benefit' captures this consistent functional provisioning semantics.
args.remark: Temporal/afterlife conditions remain captured as qualifiers on each relation instance rather than in the canonical predicate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject provides guidance or direction to the object, especially in a ritual or journey context.
args.justification: Both relations describe funerary items (texts, amulets) whose role is to guide the deceased on the journey to the afterlife; the same guidance semantics apply, so they should share a single canonical predicate 'guides'.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject engages or employs the object to fulfill a specific role within funerary activities.
args.justification: This relation expresses that the deceased's family hires/engages professional mourners for funerary duties; a specialized predicate 'employs_for_funerary_role' captures both the employment and its funerary context.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject leads, directs, or is at the head of the process or group expressed by the object.
args.justification: Professional mourners are described as leading the funeral procession; a simple, reusable predicate 'leads' correctly represents this directional/leadership role.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject carries out, executes, or performs the activity or ritual expressed by the object.
args.justification: The relation states that professional mourners carry out funerary rituals; the canonical predicate 'performs' succinctly captures this action semantics between agent and ritual.

All these relations describe the functional roles of people, objects, or structures within funerary or afterlife contexts: pyramids serving as gateways, offerings providing benefits, texts and amulets guiding, families employing mourners, and mourners leading or performing rituals. Grouping them under 'funerary_function_relation' captures this common semantic family of roles and functions in funerary practice.
args.remark: This class intentionally spans both human and non-human agents, unified by their function in funerary/afterlife contexts rather than by ontological type.

args.justification: Each relation focuses on how an entity is used or functions within a ritual/afterlife scenario—providing benefits, guiding, being employed, leading, or performing. This aligns best with a broad functional/usage dimension rather than pure causality or identity.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an item is deliberately deposited or placed inside a specific spatial container or structure (e.g., an object placed in a tomb or burial chamber as part of a ritual or assemblage).
args.justification: All four relations describe intentional deposition of funerary items (texts, amulets, papyrus scrolls, copies of the Book of the Dead) into tombs or burial chambers as part of the burial assemblage, emphasizing deliberate placement rather than mere static location.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an entity is (typically or characteristically) situated within, or contained by, a spatial region, structure, or geographic/cultural area.
args.justification: These three relations describe static or characteristic spatial containment: the Book of the Dead found in tombs, the deceased located within the tomb, and tombs located within Ancient Egypt. None emphasize the act of placement, but rather the spatial location/containment itself.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process, state, or event takes place within a specified realm, domain, or context (physical or conceptual).
args.justification: This relation links the abstract state of eternal existence to the realm of the gods; it is more naturally modeled as a state/process occurring within a conceptual realm rather than a physical object being located in a container.

All relations express spatial or spatial-like localization—either physical containment (objects in tombs or burial chambers, tombs in Egypt) or a state/process situated in a conceptual realm (eternal existence in the realm of the gods). Grouping them under a common spatial_location_relation class allows multiple canonical predicates (is_placed_in, located_in, occurs_in) while preserving a unified spatial semantics family.

Each relation fundamentally encodes where something is or takes place, whether in a physical space (tombs, burial chambers, geographic Ancient Egypt) or a conceptual locus (realm of the gods). This aligns consistently with a broad SPATIALITY class group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a practice or action is motivated or driven by a belief, goal, or underlying reason.
args.justification: The subject is a set of burial practices and the object is the underlying afterlife beliefs that drive those practices; a causal motivational predicate from subject to object is best captured as 'is_motivated_by'.
This relation links an observable practice to the beliefs that motivate it, which is a specific type of causal relation focused on motivation rather than generic cause.
The burial practices are presented as arising from or being driven by afterlife beliefs, which fits a causal/motivational dimension.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an event, process, or activity is organized around or primarily focused on a particular participant or theme.
args.justification: The funeral procession is organized around the deceased as its primary focus; a directional predicate from event to its main subject is best captured as 'is_centered_on'.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an attitude, emotion, or orientation is directed toward a particular target or object.
args.justification: The subject is reverence (an attitude) and the object is the deceased individual; the natural predicate is an attitude being directed toward its target, expressed as 'is_directed_toward'.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a belief, concept, text, or discourse has a particular topic or subject matter.
args.justification: The relation connects afterlife beliefs to the afterlife itself as their topic; an aboutness predicate like 'is_about' captures this thematic connection more clearly than the raw label.

Both relations connect an activity or belief (funeral procession, afterlife beliefs) to what they are organized around or about (the deceased, the afterlife), which is a common thematic-focus/subject-matter pattern.
This relation links an attitude (reverence) to the entity it is directed toward (the deceased), which is best captured as an attitude-to-target family of predicates.
All three relations express non-compositional, non-causal links based on focus, aboutness, or attitudinal direction, which fall under a broad associative/thematic dimension.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a complex process or ritual includes a specific subprocess, operation, or procedural step as part of its overall execution.
args.justification: All three relations describe the mummification process as a composite procedure that includes particular steps (organ removal, drying with salt, wrapping with linen). The common semantics is a whole process decomposed into constituent steps, so a single canonical predicate 'includes_process_step' fits all instances.
Each relation expresses that a complex ritual/process is composed of specific subordinate steps. This is best modeled as a process decomposition class rather than a generic composition relation.
The relations describe how a larger process is composed of constituent steps, which is a compositional (part–whole) dimension applied to processes.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject physically contains or encloses the object within its spatial boundaries (object is located inside the subject).
args.justification: All three relations describe a physical spatial containment: tombs or a burial chamber enclosing the deceased or grave goods. Despite wording differences like 'contains' vs 'houses', the underlying predicate is the same physical containment relation.
These relations all belong to the same conceptual family where one physical structure serves as the enclosing container for persons or objects (deceased, grave goods) located inside it.
The primary semantic dimension is spatial: all relations describe where the object is located relative to the subject (inside/enclosed by it), not composition, causality, or identity.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject serves to protect or safeguard the object from harm, loss, or disturbance.
args.justification: In both relations the Egyptian pyramid is described as serving a protective role toward what is buried inside (the deceased's body or grave goods). The predicate is symmetric in intent and differs only in the protected object, so a single canonical predicate 'protects' is appropriate.
args.remark: Specifics of what the pyramid protects (body vs. goods) are captured by the object entity; qualifiers capture funerary purpose.

args.justification: Both relations express the functional role of the pyramid as a protective structure for what it contains, so they naturally belong to a class of relations describing protective functions of entities.
The relations capture the intended purpose/function of the pyramid (to protect its contents), rather than composition, hierarchy, or pure causality; this fits a broad functional/usage dimension.

args.remark: Object 'grave goods' is used as a stand-in for the more general notion of the deceased's possessions; mapping is approximate but acceptable for KG purposes.
args.justification: The original remark highlights a semantic alignment issue (possessions vs. grave goods); preserving this note helps future reviewers understand the modeling choice without altering the relation schema.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links a cultural or ritual practice to a type of structure whose construction is a defining element of that practice.
args.justification: The relation states that ancient Egyptian burial practices included constructing tombs as one of their most famous aspects; this is best modeled as the practice involving the construction of a particular structure type, not as a simple part-whole relation between the practice and the tombs.

This connects a cultural practice (burial practices) with a physical structure type (tombs) that the practice constructs or uses, fitting a class for relations between practices/rituals and associated built structures.
The practice entails the construction and use of tombs, which is best captured as a usage/operational association between activity and structure rather than a pure compositional or identity relation.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a practice, institution, or subsystem forms a constituent component of a broader social or cultural system.

Each relation links a specific cultural practice to a broader cultural or societal system as one of its vital parts, which fits a relation class for components of social or cultural systems.
The semantics are explicitly about being a vital part of a larger whole (culture or society), which is a canonical compositional/part–whole relation.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject (an individual or group) holds or maintains a belief concerning the object concept, proposition, or doctrine.
args.justification: This relation links a population (ancient Egyptians) to a set of afterlife beliefs they hold. A generic cognitive-attitude predicate like 'has_belief_about' best captures that the subject is the believer and the object is the belief content.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject practice or action is performed or maintained because it is motivated or justified by the object belief, goal, or reason.
args.justification: The description states that mummification is supported and motivated by afterlife beliefs, with the practice as subject and belief as cause. A predicate in the passive-causal direction, 'is_motivated_by', correctly reflects that the subject practice stems from the object belief.
args.remark: Direction kept as in the data model: practice (mummification) as effect, beliefs as motivating cause.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject belief, goal, or rationale provides the motivation for including or using the object item or practice in a ritual, burial, or other context.
args.justification: Both relations explicitly describe afterlife beliefs as motivating the inclusion/use of specific burial items (religious texts and amulets). They share identical causal semantics (belief as cause, item usage as effect), so they should use a single canonical predicate 'motivates_use_of'.

This relation family covers links where a cognitive agent or group is attributed specific beliefs, doctrines, or mental attitudes toward concepts or propositions, matching the semantics of 'has_belief_about'.

All three relations represent a motivational causal link: beliefs motivate or underlie practices or inclusions (or a practice is motivated by beliefs). Grouping them under 'motivational_causality_relation' captures this shared pattern of reasons or beliefs causing actions.
The core semantic dimension is a cognitive/mental attitude (a group holding certain beliefs). This fits a broad mental-state category rather than general causality or composition.
Each relation encodes that certain beliefs cause, motivate, or underlie specific practices or the inclusion of items in burials, which is best modeled under a broad causal/motivational dimension.

Both relations capture that a religious or cultural practice (burial practices) depends conceptually on an underlying set of beliefs (afterlife beliefs), forming a coherent class of doctrinal or belief-based dependency relations.

The Book of the Dead relation emphasizes the functional role of the text in guiding the soul and supporting the belief system, which is best grouped under functional/usage-oriented relations rather than strict causal or compositional ones.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts referring to the dead person as the subject of ancient Egyptian burial, mummification, and afterlife practices, including both the individual and their preserved body.

cluster_classes.class_description: Interrelated concepts involved in the Ancient Egyptian mummification practice, including the core embalming process, treatment of internal organs, desiccation using salt, and wrapping with linen bandages.

members.entity_description: Ancient Egyptian burial and embalming process of preserving a corpse to prevent decay and prepare it for the afterlife, involving body preservation through organ removal, desiccation, and wrapping.

cluster_classes.class_description: Interrelated beliefs, states, locations, and processes that constitute the ancient Egyptian conception of the afterlife, including the post-death realm, the soul’s journey, desired conditions, and the divine domain of the gods.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: All entities describe aspects of the ancient Egyptian afterlife: its realm, soul’s journey, goals like safe passage and eternal existence, and provisions for comfort and sustenance.

members.entity_description: The ancient Egyptian religious conception of the afterlife, encompassing the post-death realm, the journey of the soul, associated deities, and the rituals and practices intended to ensure safe passage and eternal life.
Divine domain in ancient Egyptian belief where the gods dwell and where the deceased sought to exist eternally after successfully navigating the afterlife.
Concept of pyramids functioning as an entry point from the living world to the afterlife.
State of ease and well-being intended for the deceased through burial items.
Provision of nourishment to the deceased through items buried with them.
Spiritual component of a person believed to be reunited with the body in the afterlife.
Spiritual voyage the deceased was believed to undertake after death.
Believed post-death existence for which Egyptians prepared the deceased with tombs and grave goods.
Desired successful journey of the deceased from death to the afterlife.

members.entity_name: eternal existence in the realm of the gods

members.entity_name: reverence for the deceased in ancient Egypt

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject represents a more specific subtype or category within the broader class represented by the object.
args.justification: All relations describe a taxonomic/class-inclusion link where the subject is a more specific category of the object (e.g., food offerings as a type of grave goods, Egyptian pyramids as a type of ancient Egyptian tomb). This is best modeled as a subtype relation with consistent predicate naming.
Each relation encodes a taxonomic or categorical hierarchy (a more specific funerary/tomb category included within a broader one), so they belong to the same class of taxonomic hierarchy relations.
Subtype/supertype (is-a) hierarchies are a form of identity/typing relation, linking a more specific identity to a more general one, so they fit best in an IDENTITY-oriented high-level group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A ritual, process, or cultural practice that is carried out for, or applied to, a specific individual or social group as its target.
args.justification: All three relations link a ritual/process or burial practice to the person or social group it is directed toward or applied to (deceased individual, elite, non-elite). A unified predicate 'performed_for' captures this target/beneficiary role more cleanly and consistently than the noisy 'applied_to' or 'applies_to'.

Each relation expresses that a ritual or cultural practice has a specific target individual or social group. Grouping them under a class that captures the target of a ritual/practice is more specific and reusable than a generic class like 'association_relation'.

Conceptually these relations describe how particular practices are applied or used with respect to certain people or social strata (the practical application/usage of a ritual toward a target), which fits best under a broad USAGE-type group rather than CAUSALITY, IDENTITY, or pure ASSOCIATION.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a ritual, procedure, or practice is carried out on a specific subject or target (e.g., a deceased individual or body).
args.justification: Both relations describe funerary or mummification procedures (salt drying; general burial practices) being carried out on the deceased as the target of the action. A shared predicate 'performed_on' captures this process-to-subject application consistently.
args.remark: Temporal and spatial qualifiers (e.g., 'during mummification', 'after death', 'in tombs') remain as qualifiers on the relation instances.

args.justification: These edges link ritual/procedural practices to the subjects they are applied to; this fits a class describing how procedures are applied to or enacted upon targets.
args.remark: Covers ritual, funerary, and other procedural applications where a practice is enacted on a person or body.

args.justification: The semantics emphasize an action (ritual/procedure) interacting with and affecting a target (the deceased), which fits an action–object interaction dimension more than composition or identity.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject practice, object, or action is intended or used to achieve the object as its purpose or goal.
args.justification: All four relations describe funerary structures, practices, or texts whose intended goal is to secure the deceased's eternal existence in the realm of the gods. The semantics are teleological (purpose) with direction subject=means and object=goal, so a unified predicate 'has_purpose' is appropriate.

Each relation links a funerary practice or object to its intended function or goal in the religious system (ensuring eternal existence among the gods). This is best modeled as a functional purpose class rather than composition, identity, or hierarchy.
The relations capture how funerary elements are used or intended to be used to achieve a religious goal, fitting the broad dimension of usage/purpose rather than strict causality or identity.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links a cultural practice or custom to the underlying cultural belief, value, or attitude that it expresses or manifests.
args.justification: Both relations connect ancient Egyptian burial practices to underlying cultural beliefs/values (afterlife beliefs; reverence for the deceased). Despite slightly different surface verbs ('reflects', 'embodies'), the core semantics are that the practice expresses or manifests a cultural belief/value, so they should share one canonical predicate.

These relations describe how social or ritual practices function as expressions of underlying cultural ideas. Grouping them under a class for cultural expression/manifestation captures this shared semantic family and can apply to many similar practice–belief links.

The relations express that burial practices are manifestations of, and are partly defined by, underlying beliefs/values (a representational or identity-like link between practices and cultural ideas), which fits best under a broad IDENTITY-style group rather than causality or composition.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A belief system or broader conceptual complex includes a specific subordinate concept, element, or aspect.
args.justification: All three relations link a broader set of ancient Egyptian afterlife beliefs to particular constituent concepts (gateway, soul, journey), with the same directionality (belief system -> component concept). This is best captured as a single predicate for conceptual inclusion.
Each relation expresses that a larger belief-complex is composed of or specified by subordinate concepts; this is a conceptual component or part-whole relation within an abstract belief system.
The semantics are part-whole at the conceptual level (a belief system composed of constituent ideas), fitting the broad COMPOSITION group rather than, e.g., ASSOCIATION or CAUSALITY.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject ritual, practice, or process is intentionally performed in order to achieve or support the outcome or goal represented by the object.
args.justification: All three relations describe a teleological link where funerary practices or mummification are intentionally carried out to secure or support safe passage into the afterlife; this is best modeled as a single purpose-oriented predicate rather than generic 'used_for'.
args.remark: Object nodes may represent either outcomes (safe passage) or belief constructs about the afterlife, but at the relation level they all encode the intended goal of the practice.

args.justification: Each relation expresses that a ritual practice is directed toward an intended outcome or goal, forming a coherent family of teleological or purpose-oriented links.

The semantics match a broad 'used for / intended for' dimension: practices and processes (subjects) are used with the purpose of achieving afterlife-related outcomes (objects), fitting a USAGE-oriented grouping more than pure CAUSALITY.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject (a funerary object or text) is intentionally employed to achieve or support the object purpose or outcome.
args.justification: Both relations describe funerary items (religious texts, amulets) being intentionally included in burials in order to ensure or support safe passage into the afterlife, i.e., a shared purpose/use relation. Normalizing to a concise predicate 'used_for' captures this intended functional role without embedding qualifiers.

In both instances, the subject is a funerary text or amulet whose function is to aid the deceased in the afterlife. This is a specific subtype of purpose/function relations focused on the role of funerary objects within burial practices, so grouping them under a dedicated class clarifies their domain.

The core semantics concern how funerary items are used and what purpose they serve in ritual practice (ensuring safe passage), which fits best under a broad usage/purpose dimension rather than pure causality or composition.

args.justification: Both relations describe grave goods whose intended purpose is to provide some benefit (comfort or sustenance) to the deceased in the afterlife; the core predicate is an intention to provide a benefit, regardless of the specific type of benefit.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is intended to be used in or within a particular context or realm (here, by the deceased in the afterlife).
args.justification: These three relations describe items (grave goods, food offerings, tools) whose purpose is to be used by the deceased in the afterlife; the shared semantics is an intended use within a specific context (the afterlife realm).

All five relations connect funerary goods or offerings to aspects of the deceased's existence in the afterlife, describing how these items are meant to provide for or be used by the deceased there; grouping them under an 'afterlife_provision_relation' class captures this shared conceptual family.

Each relation expresses an intended function or use of objects (grave goods, tools, offerings) in relation to the deceased's afterlife, which fits a broad USAGE-oriented group (intended use and functional purpose) better than composition or identity.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a cultural practice, phenomenon, or cultural domain takes place within and is situated in the context of a given civilization.
args.justification: All three relations link cultural phenomena (Ancient Egyptian culture, ancient Egyptian burial practices) to the encompassing entity 'Ancient Egypt' as their civilizational context, not as a simple location or time point. A single predicate 'occurs_in_civilization' captures this shared semantics more precisely than the generic 'occurs_in'.
args.remark: Intended for cultural or social practices situated within a named civilization (spatio-temporal-cultural container), distinct from purely geographic or temporal occurrence relations.

args.justification: Each relation expresses that the subject is embedded in or defined by the cultural-historical context of a specific civilization, which is best modeled as a cultural context family of relations.
args.remark: This class can cover other predicates linking practices, beliefs, and institutions to their parent civilization or culture.

args.justification: The core semantics is that the practices or cultural domains take place 'within' the spatial-cultural bounds of Ancient Egypt; while there is a temporal aspect, the primary framing in the descriptions is a within-ness/embeddedness similar to spatial containment.
args.remark: Could alternatively be seen as spatio-temporal context; for now grouped under SPATIALITY to align with the dominant 'within' formulation.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject (a practice, artifact, or behavior) serves as an expression or manifestation of the object (a belief, value, or attitude).
args.justification: All three relations describe ancient Egyptian burial practices serving as an expression or manifestation of underlying beliefs or reverence; they share the same predicate semantics (practices expressing cultural/ religious concepts) and differ only in wording such as 'reflects' vs 'expresses' vs 'manifest'.

These links connect cultural practices to the beliefs or values they express, forming a coherent family of relations where practices function as expressions of underlying cultural or religious concepts.

The semantics are about representation/manifestation (burial practices representing or expressing beliefs and reverence), not composition, causality, or hierarchy; a broad group focused on representational relations is most appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an event, process, or practice involves a specific participant (person, group, or role) taking part in it.
args.justification: All four relations connect an event or ritual process (journey to the afterlife; burial practices) to human actors or roles (the deceased, priests, embalmers, other specialists) that take part in or are required for the process. This is a standard event–participant predicate, so a unified canonical_rel_name 'has_participant' best captures the semantics.

Each relation describes which actors participate in or are involved in a ritual or process. This is a clear case of an event–participant or process–participant family of relations, appropriately captured by the class label 'participation_relation'.

These links specify which agents (the deceased, priests, embalmers, other specialists) are involved in carrying out or experiencing an event or process. This is best categorized under a broad AGENCY dimension, emphasizing involvement of actors in actions or rituals.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the deceased individual is interred together with specific grave goods as part of the funerary assemblage.
args.justification: Both relations describe deceased persons being interred accompanied by grave goods in the same direction (person → goods) as part of burial practice; they share identical predicate semantics, so they should use a single normalized canonical predicate.

Both instances express that certain objects (grave goods) are included in a burial alongside a deceased individual, reflecting a specific type of funerary practice relation (what is included with whom in the burial). Grouping them under a dedicated funerary_inclusion_relation class captures this shared semantics.

The core meaning is that the deceased and the grave goods are intentionally associated together in the burial context (accompaniment / co-occurrence in a ritual assemblage), which best fits a broad ASSOCIATION group rather than pure COMPOSITION or SPATIALITY.

executed_decisions.justification: Both relations describe deceased persons being interred accompanied by grave goods in the same direction (person → goods) as part of burial practice; they share identical predicate semantics, so they should use a single normalized canonical predicate.

Both instances express that certain objects (grave goods) are included in a burial alongside a deceased individual, reflecting a specific type of funerary practice relation (what is included with whom in the burial). Grouping them under a dedicated funerary_inclusion_relation class captures this shared semantics.

The core meaning is that the deceased and the grave goods are intentionally associated together in the burial context (accompaniment / co-occurrence in a ritual assemblage), which best fits a broad ASSOCIATION group rather than pure COMPOSITION or SPATIALITY.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links an afterlife condition, state, or benefit to the deceased individual who is intended to experience or receive it.
args.justification: In both relations the subject is an afterlife state/benefit (safe passage; eternal existence in the realm of the gods) and the object is the deceased, marked as beneficiary/experiencer. A unified predicate capturing 'afterlife outcome/benefit for the deceased' fits both instances and normalizes minor wording differences in the noisy relation_name field.

Both relations describe how specific afterlife conditions function as benefits or intended experiential states for the deceased individual, forming a coherent class of 'afterlife benefit/experience' relations.

The core semantics involve a participant role (the deceased) as the beneficiary/experiencer of an outcome, which fits a broad group concerned with participant roles and affected parties better than composition, identity, or simple association.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a tomb or burial structure is intended to serve as the burial place for a specific person or social group, typically in the afterlife context.
args.justification: Both relations describe the same core predicate: ancient Egyptian tombs are constructed with the purpose of housing particular persons (pharaohs or elite) after death. The direction (tomb → person/group) and semantics (intended burial place/purpose) are identical, so they should share a single canonical predicate capturing that these structures function as the burial place for the referenced individuals.
args.remark: Qualifiers like 'after death' and 'in the afterlife' are instance-level temporal/intended-realm details and should remain as qualifiers, not be folded into the canonical predicate.

args.justification: These relations connect tomb structures to the persons or social groups they are meant to house in death, reflecting the intended funerary/burial purpose of the structures. Grouping them under a more specific class 'burial_purpose_relation' (rather than a generic 'purpose_relation') better captures the consistent funerary semantics across such links.

The primary semantic dimension is that tombs are used/intended to be used as burial places for specific individuals or groups, which is a purpose/usage relationship rather than composition, identity, or causality. Therefore, these relations best fit under a broad USAGE group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a structure was constructed for the benefit, use, or commemoration of a particular person or social group.
args.justification: The relation links tomb structures to the elite they were intended for; this is a beneficiary/intended-recipient relation, so a predicate like 'was_built_for' best captures that semantics.
The tombs are constructed for a specific social group (elite), which is a typical beneficiary/intended-recipient pattern rather than composition or hierarchy.
Building tombs for the elite encodes intended use/benefit by a target group; this fits a broad USAGE/beneficiary dimension more than causality or identity.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an agent or group does not have sufficient resources (e.g., economic, material) to construct or create a specified type of structure or artifact.
args.justification: The relation describes that non-elite Egyptians did not have the resources required to build pyramids; this is a lack-of-resources-to-perform-construction relation, so 'lacks_resources_to_build' captures the constraint.
The core semantics is an economic/resource limitation preventing an action (building pyramids), which is best modeled as a resource constraint relation.
This relation expresses that necessary resource requirements for building pyramids are not met; this aligns with a broad REQUIREMENT/constraint dimension.
